boat.name: Shamrock
boat.full_description:
Built in Frederick Hawke's Stonehouse Yard in 1899, 'Shamrock' started her career as a ketch rigged sailing barge to carry cargo between Plymouth and Torpoint. After World War I, in 1919, she was sold for £600 to a group of quarrymen and had an engine installed. She was then used for carrying stone from the River Lynher quarries to Dartmouth and Falmouth.

Continuing work as a cargo barge, including salvage and dredging in the South West, she was eventually laid up in 1973 at Hooe Lake, near Plymouth in a derelict state. Rescued by the National Trust, she was taken to Cotehele Quay for restoration in 1974.
boat.short_description: 'Shamrock' is probably the last fully restored working Tamar sailing barge, kept at Cotehele Quay, a National Trust property on the River Tamar, Cornwall.
